mainHeading: Text augmentation using LLMs in Medical Transcripts.
context: A research project focused on handling class imbalance in medical transcription datasets by generating synthetic data using Large Language Models and comparing their effectiveness against traditional augmentation methods.
objectives: Augmented a highly imbalanced medical transcription dataset using LLMs like ClinicalBERT, ALBERT, GPT-Neo, and T5
Generated approximately 800 synthetic samples to boost minority class representation
Benchmarked LLM-based augmentation against SMOTE using two model architectures
Trained and evaluated CNN and CNN+BiLSTM classifiers on the augmented datasets
Demonstrated the effectiveness of domain-specific LLMs in improving minority class accuracy
features: Domain-specific augmentation using ClinicalBERT and ALBERT
Applied text-to-text generation and paraphrasing using T5 and GPT-Neo
Implemented synonym replacement and strategic masking techniques
Achieved 94% accuracy with ALBERT and 93% with ClinicalBERT on CNN classifiers
Outperformed traditional SMOTE baseline which achieved only 53% accuracy
